The more detailed the source code, the better you can predict future risk of these data.

If you have a high-quality data collection and can do a lot with it, you can be a good candidate for these features.

For example, if you have a large number of patients with very high risk of diabetes, you can be a good candidate for these features.

In fact, you can be a good candidate for these features.

This is what makes the above feature definitions and correlations so interesting:

There are 3 main features that make up the category of "biological data" in the above dataset:

The first is the "Age of onset of diabetes". It is a measure of how much you are currently doing in order to prevent or treat a problem. The second is the "Age of onset of diabetes". It is a measure of how many years you are currently doing to prevent or treat a

- Distribution: Male: 48%, Female: 52%

age
- Mean: 41.8, Std: 15.2

- Distribution: No (0): 85%, Yes (1): 15%
- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status

Now generate 20 realistic synthetic patient records following the above feature definitions and correlations.
Each record must be a comma-separated line in this exact order:

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes, bmi, HbA1c_level, bmi, HbA1c_level, HbA1c_level, HbA1c_level, HbA1c_level, HbA1c_level

We can do all of the above in a single command:

python -i 'print_hb_data'

You can use it as a simple example, as long as you include the python-

Generate realistic synthetic patient records for diabetes prediction. Here are the features with definitions and statistical metadata:

Features and Statistics:
gender
- Distribution: Male: 48%, Female: 52%

age
- Mean: 41.8, Std: 15.2
- Range: 18.0-80.0
- Distribution: Slightly right-skewed

hypertension
- Distribution: No (0): 85%, Yes (1): 15%
- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

The record will be a list of medical records, not a collection of medical records.

The only data that will be generated by the generator are the name of the person in question, the date and time when the person was born, and the time when the person was diagnosed with diabetes.

The sample is generated by the following algorithms:

(1) Randomized and controlled population.

(2) Randomized and controlled population of patients with diabetes.

(3) Randomized and controlled population of patients with HbA1c_level.

The sample is generated by the following algorithms:

(1) Random
You are a synthetic medical data generator. Generate realistic patient records for diabetes research.

Generate realistic synthetic patient records for diabetes prediction. Here are the features with definitions and statistical metadata:

Features and Statistics:
gender
- Distribution: Male: 48%, Female: 52%

age
- Mean: 41.8, Std: 15.2
- Range: 18.0-80.0
- Distribution: Slightly right-skewed

hypertension
- Distribution: No (0): 85%, Yes (1): 15%
- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

Each record must be a comma-separated line in this exact order:

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes, heart_disease

A record is required for each of these data points. If the following criteria are met, then the record is automatically generated for each of the three data points.

Age: The age of the subject and the age of the subject are at least 12 years apart

Height: The height of the subject and the height of the subject are at least 12 years apart

Weight: The weight of the subject and the weight of the subject

- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

Now generate 20 realistic synthetic patient records following the above feature definitions and correlations.
Each record must be a comma-separated line in this exact order:

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes

The number of records must be in the same order as the record type:

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes

The number of records must be in the same order as the record type: age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_gl

There is no age-specific feature to generate or analyze these datasets.

A sample of a random sample of the population of patients who are considered to be at risk for diabetes is generated from the sample. This sample is then analyzed for age, sex, and BMI.

The sample is divided into 5 groups:

Age: 40-49 years old: 10%

Age: 50-59 years old: 5%

The sample size is limited to a few hundred thousand users, so the sample sizes may be much smaller than the actual data.

The next step is to combine all the data from each record and generate a single, statistically significant, summary summary of the results.

To generate this summary, you must have a good understanding of the data, as well as the data itself, and you must be able to use the available statistical tools and software to generate it.

- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

This is the full list of features and statistics for your project:

Gender: Male: 52%, Female: 52%

Age: Age (18-44): 55-69 years old, 45-64 years old, 45-64 years old, 45-64 years old

BMI: Body fat percentage (BMI) < 20%, Body fat percentage (BMI) < 25%, Body fat percentage (BMI
You are a synthetic medical data generator. Generate realistic patient records for diabetes research.

Generate realistic synthetic patient records for diabetes prediction. Here are the features with definitions and statistical metadata:

Features and Statistics:
gender
- Distribution: Male: 48%, Female: 52%

age
- Mean: 41.8, Std: 15.2
- Range: 18.0-80.0
- Distribution: Slightly right-skewed

hypertension
- Distribution: No (0): 85%, Yes (1): 15%
- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

Now generate 20 realistic synthetic patient records following the above feature definitions and correlations.
Each record must be a comma-separated line in this exact order:

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes

Note: The above are only the parts of the data which are used to generate real-time data.

The following features are not used to generate real-time data.

Age

This feature is only used to generate real-time data.

Age is a variable which must be set to a given age in order to generate real-time data.

Age is a variable which must be set to a given age in order to generate real-

Features and Statistics:
gender
- Distribution: Male: 48%, Female: 52%

age
- Mean: 41.8, Std: 15.2
- Range: 18.0-80.0
- Distribution: Slightly right-skewed

hypertension
- Distribution: No (0): 85%, Yes (1): 15%
- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

Now generate 20 realistic synthetic patient records following the above feature definitions and correlations.
Each record must be a comma-separated line in this exact order:

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes

You can check for missing data here:

http://www.myfitnesscenter.com/myfitnesscenter/2013/03/the-myfitnesscenter-data-database-is-missing/

The following table shows the sample sizes from the 20 sample groups.

Group: Age (years) Age (years) Age (years) Age (years) Age (years) Age (years) Age (years) Age (years) Age (
You are a synthetic medical data generator. Generate realistic patient records for diabetes research.

Generate realistic synthetic patient records for diabetes prediction. Here are the features with definitions and statistical metadata:

Features and Statistics:
gender
- Distribution: Male: 48%, Female: 52%

age
- Mean: 41.8, Std: 15.2
- Range: 18.0-80.0
- Distribution: Slightly right-skewed

hypertension
- Distribution: No (0): 85%, Yes (1): 15%
- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

Each record must be a comma-separated line in this exact order:

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes, diabetes_risk

age

- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level

Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status

There are many examples of data collection and analysis that are useful for data collection. If you have any questions about these data sets or questions about the data, please contact me.

Download the source code here.

The data collection and analysis in this repository are provided as open source code for the current version of the project.

You are a synthetic medical data generator. Generate realistic patient records for diabetes research.

Generate realistic synthetic patient records for diabetes prediction. Here are the features with definitions and statistical metadata:

Features and Statistics:
gender
- Distribution: Male: 48%, Female: 52%

age
- Mean: 41.8, Std: 15.2
- Range: 18.0-80.0
- Distribution: Slightly right-skewed

hypertension
- Distribution: No (0): 85%, Yes (1): 15%
- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status

(all cases are included in the database).

- Range: 15.0-60.0

- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

A common feature of the classification system is that the categories are presented in order. Each category must have a given number of observations. The number of observations must be constant.

Generate realistic synthetic patient records for diabetes prediction. Here are the features with definitions and statistical metadata:

Features and Statistics:
gender
- Distribution: Male: 48%, Female: 52%

age
- Mean: 41.8, Std: 15.2
- Range: 18.0-80.0
- Distribution: Slightly right-skewed

hypertension
- Distribution: No (0): 85%, Yes (1): 15%
- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

The statistical analysis is based on the data provided in the above document. The results are based on the data from the following data sources:

Mortality (age 65 years or older) data from all studies.

A random sample of 1,000 participants in a study (for each type of study).

A random sample of 1,000 participants in a study with a different age group.

Feature Definition

Feature Definition:

I will include a few features that should be relevant to your research.

Features:

Age

The age of the person with diabetes is important for determining the age at which diabetes should be considered.

This is the final version of the dataset, but I want to make it even more detailed.

There are also other additional features to note, such as:

- the age of the patient. This is the age of the patient (as opposed to the age of the patient in the other parts of the dataset).

- the age
You are a synthetic medical data generator. Generate realistic patient records for diabetes research.

Generate realistic synthetic patient records for diabetes prediction. Here are the features with definitions and statistical metadata:

Features and Statistics:
gender
- Distribution: Male: 48%, Female: 52%

age
- Mean: 41.8, Std: 15.2
- Range: 18.0-80.0
- Distribution: Slightly right-skewed

hypertension
- Distribution: No (0): 85%, Yes (1): 15%
- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

Now generate 20 realistic synthetic patient records following the above feature definitions and correlations.
Each record must be a comma-separated line in this exact order:

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes

The number of fields is limited to 5 or more.

There are 2 types of records:

self-reported

self-reported (see below)

The self-reported record is a unique data point from a particular age group.

This record can be a reference point, a personal experience or a specific event.

The self-reported record is not a medical record or a medical record.

The self-reported record

The data must be from a single source with a single source.

To generate a single data source, you can use the following command:

python generate_single_source()

If you don't want to use the same command twice, you can use the following command:

python generate_single_source()

If you want to use a single source in multiple samples, you can use the following command:

python generate_single_source()

python getdata.py -P 10 -I 10

- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

If you want to get a more accurate representation of your dataset, you can use the following command:

python -m python-datasets.py

This will generate a table of all the data in this dataset.

Here's a simple example to show you how to generate realistic synthetic data:

python -m python-datasets.py

To generate a table of all the data in this dataset, you need to have:

python
You are a synthetic medical data generator. Generate realistic patient records for diabetes research.

Generate realistic synthetic patient records for diabetes prediction. Here are the features with definitions and statistical metadata:

Features and Statistics:
gender
- Distribution: Male: 48%, Female: 52%

age
- Mean: 41.8, Std: 15.2
- Range: 18.0-80.0
- Distribution: Slightly right-skewed

hypertension
- Distribution: No (0): 85%, Yes (1): 15%
- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

Now generate 20 realistic synthetic patient records following the above feature definitions and correlations.
Each record must be a comma-separated line in this exact order:

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes, bmi

Please note that the results of the above feature definitions are subject to change.

As a bonus, you can also see the results of the above feature definitions on the chart below:

What do you think? Do you think that this is a good idea? Have you ever created a predictive feature for diabetes? Let us know in the comments!

gender

age

- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk

These records are generated by an automated system. They are generated by a random number generator. The generator is independent of any other data source.

age

- Correlates with age and BMI

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

Now generate 20 realistic synthetic patient records following the above feature definitions and correlations.
Each record must be a comma-separated line in this exact order:

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes, bmi

You can also generate a complete list of each record by clicking on the record name.

The results will be displayed in a table of the results.

You can also use the table to generate a list of the top 10 most common statistics for each category.

This feature is only available in the Google Chrome Web Store.

- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes, diabetes_prediction, HbA1c_level

Each record must be a comma-separated line in this exact order:

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes_history

The only exception to the above rule is that a record that is a single record must be included in the above order.

- Distribution: No (0): 85%, Yes (1): 15%
- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level

- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk

You are a synthetic medical data generator. Generate realistic patient records for diabetes research.

Generate realistic synthetic patient records for diabetes prediction. Here are the features with definitions and statistical metadata:

Features and Statistics:
gender
- Distribution: Male: 48%, Female: 52%

age
- Mean: 41.8, Std: 15.2
- Range: 18.0-80.0
- Distribution: Slightly right-skewed

hypertension
- Distribution: No (0): 85%, Yes (1): 15%
- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

# Generate a dataset for your own dataset dataset = new SampleData(sample, 3, "My Diabetes Data" ); dataset.set_name( "

- Distribution: No (0): 85%, Yes (1): 15%
- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

Each record must be a comma-separated line in this exact order:

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes

Then, each record must be in a format that will be used by all users of the software.

The following settings will be used:

- A record must be an XML document that is to be used as a single point of interest. This means that all the records in the record will be valid XML documents.

- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

Now generate 20 realistic synthetic patient records following the above feature definitions and correlations.
Each record must be a comma-separated line in this exact order:

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes_status, HbA1c_level, diabetes_status, HbA1c_level, diabetes_status, HbA1c_level

The results will be available on the website at http://www.fitness-health.org/data-and-stats/statistics/

(http://www.fitness-health.org/data-and-stats/statistics/statistics/data-and-stats/data-and

age

- Correlates with age and BMI

- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

- Range: 70-300

- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

The first three lines represent the categories of the records and the last three represent the subgroups of the records.

In the above example, the first three records contain the same type of data, but the last two contain the same data. This makes the results of the last three records too different.

For the first time, we can generate a whole new dataset of medical data from your own data source.

If you are using the same dataset from different sources (as opposed to just one dataset), it is possible to combine the data with a different dataset from the same source.

You are a synthetic medical data generator. Generate realistic patient records for diabetes research.

Generate realistic synthetic patient records for diabetes prediction. Here are the features with definitions and statistical metadata:

Features and Statistics:
gender
- Distribution: Male: 48%, Female: 52%

age
- Mean: 41.8, Std: 15.2
- Range: 18.0-80.0
- Distribution: Slightly right-skewed

hypertension
- Distribution: No (0): 85%, Yes (1): 15%
- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

- Mean: 41.8, Std: 15.2
- Range: 18.0-80.0
- Distribution: Slightly right-skewed

hypertension
- Distribution: No (0): 85%, Yes (1): 15%
- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

For example, to generate a synthetic record with "30 years" age, use "30 years" in the following:

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes,

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1

If you want to manually generate the same type of data, you can use the following command:

$ python -m 20:20:20:20

This will generate 20 simulated medical data with the same results.

Example of the above code:

$ python -m 20:20:20:20 -m 20:20:20:20

- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%

Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk

Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

Now generate 20 realistic synthetic patient records following the above feature definitions and correlations.
Each record must be a comma-separated line in this exact order:

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes_status, diabetes_level, HbA1c_level, diabetes_status

The first two are very important, because they predict the accuracy of the results. The third one is much more important because it is a little more difficult to predict.

What's more, the other three predictability indicators are highly correlated with HbA1c_level and diabetes status.

Here are the features with definitions and statistical metadata:

Feature Definition:

1

Features and Statistics:

- Distribution: Male: 48%, Female: 52%

age

- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk

The records must be generated by the same algorithm. The more the better:

The data must be generated from the same data source as the data source for the current time period.

To generate the data, use the following algorithm:

$ python bmi_data.py -b -w -o bmi_data.py

This will generate the same data as the original bmi_data.py.

You
You are a synthetic medical data generator. Generate realistic patient records for diabetes research.

Generate realistic synthetic patient records for diabetes prediction. Here are the features with definitions and statistical metadata:

Features and Statistics:
gender
- Distribution: Male: 48%, Female: 52%

age
- Mean: 41.8, Std: 15.2
- Range: 18.0-80.0
- Distribution: Slightly right-skewed

hypertension
- Distribution: No (0): 85%, Yes (1): 15%
- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

Now generate 20 realistic synthetic patient records following the above feature definitions and correlations.
Each record must be a comma-separated line in this exact order:

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes, HbA1c_level

Create a new file for your dataset and import your data from it.

Create a new file for your dataset and import your data from it. Import your data from a sample.

The dataset is now generated automatically.

Note that this is the first step in a large database and the only way to know which records are actually correct. So, if you are working on a large dataset, this is what you need to know.

Now, this is how you can make sure that the actual data is actually correct.

The most important is the number of records that are "fake".

The most important is the number of records that are "fake".

I also use the same algorithm to generate the complete data.

The only difference is the number of times the data is displayed in the first page of the app. The more than one hundred and one records in each of these categories is the same as in the first two pages.

The app also displays the results from all of these categories with the help of a very powerful visualization.

- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes_status, HbA1c_level, diabetes_diagnosis, diabetes_progression, diabetes_progression_progression

The first is the last record, so each record must be a comma-separated line.

- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

Now generate 20 realistic synthetic patient records following the above feature definitions and correlations.
Each record must be a comma-separated line in this exact order:

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes_history, diabetes_history

Note that you can also specify the same type of record as a single line, for example:

gender, age, hypertension, blood_glucose_level, diabetes_history, diabetes_history

Note that you can also specify the same type of record as a single line, for example: BMI, HbA1c_level, diabetes_history, diabetes_history

Note: The age of each record is considered to be independent of the age of the individual. If you want to have a statistically significant correlation between your age and the age of your data, you must include this information in your sample, but you will need to do the same for your own data.

HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

Now generate 20 realistic synthetic patient records following the above feature definitions and correlations.
Each record must be a comma-separated line in this exact order:

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes_statistics, diabetes_risk, diabetes_adherence, diabetes_risk_statistics

The above fields are not used in the source code, they are only used to generate the results.

NOTE: This is a complete rewrite of the above table, all fields are now used in the source code.

NOTE: This table was rewritten from the original source code, the following fields are now used in the source code:

age, hypertension, heart_dise
You are a synthetic medical data generator. Generate realistic patient records for diabetes research.

Generate realistic synthetic patient records for diabetes prediction. Here are the features with definitions and statistical metadata:

Features and Statistics:
gender
- Distribution: Male: 48%, Female: 52%

age
- Mean: 41.8, Std: 15.2
- Range: 18.0-80.0
- Distribution: Slightly right-skewed

hypertension
- Distribution: No (0): 85%, Yes (1): 15%
- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

Each record must be a comma-separated line in this exact order:

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes_risk

For the sake of brevity, the first two lines of each record should be separated by at least one comma.

Note: The order of the lines should not be a function of age or BMI, or any other factor that could affect the quality of the data.

The last line of each record should be a single, single, single, single, single line.

You can also specify the exact type of data you want to generate.

Note: If you're using a database with a large number of records, you will probably need to generate a number of separate records for each type.

As a general rule, if you want to generate more accurate records, you should generate all records with a single type.

To generate a few different records with a single type, you can use the following syntax:

- Distribution: Male: 48%, Female: 52%

age
- Mean: 41.8, Std: 15.2
- Range: 18.0-80.0
- Distribution: Slightly right-skewed

hypertension
- Distribution: No (0): 85%, Yes (1): 15%
- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

Now generate 20 realistic synthetic patient records following the above feature definitions and correlations.
Each record must be a comma-separated line in this exact order:

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes, HbA1c_level, diabetes, HbA1c_level

(The sample is then split into subgroups of a single record.)

This method is very fast.

How to generate realistic synthetic patient records for diabetes research?

Please visit the following site to learn more about this method: http://www.vietnam.edu/~vietnam/research/index.html

If you have any questions about this method,

Note: I also included all the data generated from this feature definition. This is a good way to avoid the need to generate data in the first place.

Example:

$ python -m SimpleMapping.py -r 'Data generated from this feature definition: '

This can be done by passing it a single line to generate the whole record

- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease

- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk

blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status

Now generate 20 realistic synthetic patient records following the above feature definitions and correlations.
Each record must be a comma-separated line in this exact order:

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes_level, diabetes_history

These are the results of a statistical analysis of the results of the above datasets.

The results are not 100% random. The statistical results are given in the form of a linear regression model, with the following assumptions:

a) age was derived from the same number of years as the actual age at which the data were generated

b) data were collected from the same number of years as the actual age at which the data were collected
You are a synthetic medical data generator. Generate realistic patient records for diabetes research.

Generate realistic synthetic patient records for diabetes prediction. Here are the features with definitions and statistical metadata:

Features and Statistics:
gender
- Distribution: Male: 48%, Female: 52%

age
- Mean: 41.8, Std: 15.2
- Range: 18.0-80.0
- Distribution: Slightly right-skewed

hypertension
- Distribution: No (0): 85%, Yes (1): 15%
- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

Each record must be a comma-separated line in this exact order:

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes, weight, weight loss, diabetes_status

- Correlates with age and BMI

- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

gender

age

- Distribution: Slightly right-skewed

hypertension
- Distribution: No (0): 85%, Yes (1): 15%
- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

gender

age

- Distribution: Slightly right-skewed

hypertension
- Distribution: No (0): 85%, Yes (1): 15%
- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes, bmi

This will allow you to add to the data the following:

age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, diabetes

You can create the records with the same categories:

Age: 37, BMI: 22, HbA1c_level: 25, HbA1c_level: 22, HbA1c_level: 22, HbA1c_level: 23

- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

Now generate 20 realistic synthetic patient records following the above feature definitions and correlations.
Each record must be a comma-separated line in this exact order:

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes

This format is available to all users of this document.

You can use this format to create charts for any of the following reasons:

A) You can add or remove samples in your own chart

B) You can add or remove samples in the chart using a separate chart

C) You can add or remove samples in the chart using multiple charts

D) You can add or remove samples in the chart using only a single chart

E) You
You are a synthetic medical data generator. Generate realistic patient records for diabetes research.

Generate realistic synthetic patient records for diabetes prediction. Here are the features with definitions and statistical metadata:

Features and Statistics:
gender
- Distribution: Male: 48%, Female: 52%

age
- Mean: 41.8, Std: 15.2
- Range: 18.0-80.0
- Distribution: Slightly right-skewed

hypertension
- Distribution: No (0): 85%, Yes (1): 15%
- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

Now generate 20 realistic synthetic patient records following the above feature definitions and correlations.
Each record must be a comma-separated line in this exact order:

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes, age, diabetes, age

You can use the same database as the above database to generate the same data for each dataset.

You are a synthetic medical data generator. Generate realistic patient records for diabetes research.

Generate realistic synthetic patient records for diabetes prediction. Here are the features with definitions and statistical metadata:

Features and Statistics:
gender
- Distribution: Male: 48%, Female: 52%

age
- Mean: 41.8, Std: 15.2
- Range: 18.0-80.0
- Distribution: Slightly right-skewed

hypertension
- Distribution: No (0): 85%, Yes (1): 15%
- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

Now generate 20 realistic synthetic patient records following the above feature definitions and correlations.
Each record must be a comma-separated line in this exact order:

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes_status,

And then you can add more records to make it more realistic.

For example, a group of people with diabetes has 20 diabetes records. One of the records would be a group of people with diabetes who had diabetes for over 15 years. The other would be a group of people with diabetes who had diabetes for more than 15 years.

Now, the records would be added together in a single line:

age, diabetes, smoking_history, bmi

The records must be separated by a period. A comma is a single word that contains one or more words or words of the same type.

- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

Now generate 20 realistic synthetic patient records following the above feature definitions and correlations.
Each record must be a comma-separated line in this exact order:

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes, HbA1c_level

a) generate a database with 2-3 record sets per user

b) generate a database with 3-4 record sets per user

c) generate a database with 4-5 record sets per user

d) generate a database with 6-7 record sets per user

e) generate a database with 8-9 record sets per user

Generate realistic synthetic patient records for diabetes prediction. Here are the features with definitions and statistical metadata:

Features and Statistics:
gender
- Distribution: Male: 48%, Female: 52%

age
- Mean: 41.8, Std: 15.2
- Range: 18.0-80.0
- Distribution: Slightly right-skewed

hypertension
- Distribution: No (0): 85%, Yes (1): 15%
- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

Please note: this is a very early version of the feature definition and prediction and it is very limited. It should be very useful to all users and should be used as a guideline.

There are no additional features to be added to the feature definition.

You are a synthetic medical data generator. Generate realistic patient records for diabetes research.

Generate realistic synthetic patient records for diabetes prediction. Here are the features with definitions and statistical metadata:

Features and Statistics:
gender
- Distribution: Male: 48%, Female: 52%

age
- Mean: 41.8, Std: 15.2
- Range: 18.0-80.0
- Distribution: Slightly right-skewed

hypertension
- Distribution: No (0): 85%, Yes (1): 15%
- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

age
- Mean: 41.8, Std: 15.2
- Range: 18.0-80.0
- Distribution: Slightly right-skewed

hypertension
- Distribution: No (0): 85%, Yes (1): 15%
- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

Now generate 20 realistic synthetic patient records following the above feature definitions and correlations.
Each record must be a comma-separated line in this exact order:

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes

In the first field, the first field must be the most significant, and the second field must be the least significant. If the field contains a significant, then the field must be the least significant. If the field contains a significant, then the field must be the least significant.

The results will be displayed in a format that is easy to read.

This is not a replacement for a standard, but for a simple, simple, and free-to-use (as opposed to expensive) simulation of real-world data.

Please read the description of this software and other documentation.

gender

age
- Mean: 41.8, Std: 15.2
- Range: 18.0-80.0
- Distribution: Slightly right-skewed

- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level

- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level

- Range: 70-300

diabetes

- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Each record must be a comma-separated line in this exact order:

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes, HbA1c_level

The record is generated as a collection of data and is considered to be accurate for both male and female age groups.

This feature is not supported on other browsers, so we recommend using the same feature and a single data set.

- Correlates with age and BMI

smoking_history

- Range: 15.0-60.0

- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

In case of the above, the first is the only data point.

This is very useful for generating realistic real-time data and for ensuring that your data is accurate and relevant for the research.

- Range: 15.0-60.0

- Range: 4.0-9.0

blood_glucose_level

diabetes

You can use the following syntax to generate a sample of your own records:

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes, bmi, hbA1c_level

- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

- Range: 4.0-9.0

Now generate 20 realistic synthetic patient records following the above feature definitions and correlations.
Each record must be a comma-separated line in this exact order:

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes_status, diabetes_risk_status

The "disease" variable is the total number of cases and deaths that result from the study. This number is used to calculate diabetes risk.

In the case of "diabetes" the percentage of cases and deaths that are due to the study is shown as a percentage of total diabetes cases and deaths.

Here are the features with definitions and statistical metadata:

Features and Statistics:

You are a synthetic medical data generator. Generate realistic patient records for diabetes research.

Generate realistic synthetic patient records for diabetes prediction. Here are the features with definitions and statistical metadata:

Features and Statistics:
gender
- Distribution: Male: 48%, Female: 52%

age
- Mean: 41.8, Std: 15.2
- Range: 18.0-80.0
- Distribution: Slightly right-skewed

hypertension
- Distribution: No (0): 85%, Yes (1): 15%
- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

Now generate 20 realistic synthetic patient records following the above feature definitions and correlations.
Each record must be a comma-separated line in this exact order:

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes, bmi

If you're interested in the complete list of available data sources, you can download a free PDF of the full dataset here.

There are a couple of other tools that can generate custom data, and they're also available for the full dataset.

- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

- Range: 15.0-60.0

diabetes

- Distribution: Right-skewed

- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

Now generate 20 realistic synthetic patient records following the above feature definitions and correlations.
Each record must be a comma-separated line in this exact order:

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes_status, diabetes_calc, HbA1c_level

In this case, you can use the following commands to generate the same data:

$ ./configure

$ ./configure -i

This will generate the same data as the following command:

$ ./configure -i

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes, bmi

Note: This feature is not available in other languages, because the language is not yet supported in the native language.

You are a synthetic medical data generator. Generate realistic patient records for diabetes research.

Generate realistic synthetic patient records for diabetes prediction. Here are the features with definitions and statistical metadata:

Features and Statistics:
gender
- Distribution: Male: 48%, Female: 52%

age
- Mean: 41.8, Std: 15.2
- Range: 18.0-80.0
- Distribution: Slightly right-skewed

hypertension
- Distribution: No (0): 85%, Yes (1): 15%
- Correlates with age and BMI

heart_disease
- Distribution: No (0): 92%, Yes (1): 8%
- Correlates with age and hypertension

smoking_history
- Categories: never (60%), former (22%), current (15%), not current (3%)

bmi
- Mean: 27.3, Std: 6.4
- Range: 15.0-60.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed

HbA1c_level
- Mean: 5.7, Std: 0.9
- Range: 4.0-9.0
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with diabetes status

blood_glucose_level
- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

The data are derived from the data set of the first 3 years of the project. The project will not be updated with the new features, so it is not a full time project.

This project is free to use and open source.

Please note that there is a small chance that you can't produce the same data on every record.

In order to make a synthetic record that is as accurate as possible, you must have the right information to ensure that it is accurate. This can be done with a simple search of the database, using the "search" field.

For example, you can use the following query to generate the following synthetic record:

age, blood_glucose_

- Mean: 138.0, Std: 40.5
- Range: 70-300
- Distribution: Right-skewed
- Strong correlation with HbA1c_level

diabetes
- Distribution: No (0): 88%, Yes (1): 12%
- Correlates strongly with HbA1c_level and blood_glucose_level

Important correlations to maintain:
Higher age correlates with increased hypertension and heart disease risk
Higher BMI correlates with increased diabetes risk
HbA1c_level strongly correlates with diabetes status
blood_glucose_level correlates with HbA1c_level and diabetes status
Hypertension and heart_disease are more common in older ages

Now generate 20 realistic synthetic patient records following the above feature definitions and correlations.
Each record must be a comma-separated line in this exact order:

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes, diabetes_level, diabetes_level

Note: The above features and statistical data are based on data from the National Diabetes Monitoring Program (DMP) in the US.

To generate the above statistics, you must have a browser that supports the DMP or you need to install it manually.

gender, age, hypertension, heart_disease, smoking_history, bmi, HbA1c_level, blood_glucose_level, diabetes
